item.title: Weekly Recap - 2025-04-18
item.description: Check out this week from Dev Leader! Here's a list including articles and videos on software engineering, career development, and programming in C#!

item.title: How to Get an Free Azure Subscription for Learning
item.description: Microsoft Azure Account for Free

item.title: 15,000 lines of verified cryptography now in Python
item.description: In November 2022, I opened issue 99108 on Python‚Äôs GitHub repository, arguing that after a recent CVE in its implementation of SHA3, Python should embrace verified code for all of its hash-related infrastructure.

item.title: Anchor Screws
Careers at arXiv - arXiv info
item.description: arXiv is part of Cornell Tech, the graduate campus and research center of Cornell University. All arXiv employees are Cornell University employees.

item.title: Understanding Microservices: Core Concepts and Benefits
item.description: What are microservices, and why might they be the right architectural choice for your organization? Microservices offer independently deployable, domain-focused components that provide flexibility when applied correctly to solve the right organizational problems.

item.title: The world needs you to consume less news
item.description: It‚Äôs considered good and upstanding to stay on top of world affairs. You want to be educated about the world, right? But there is so much to keep up on. So much injustice to counter. I‚Äôm here to tell you that the world needs you to consume less news. I know you‚Äôre doing it from a good place but I think you should take a break. First, the expectation to ‚Äústay on top of things‚Äù is a modern invention. Something only possible during the most recent fraction of human history. For most of history, news travelled slowly‚Äîby word of mouth, by post, by pigeon. Now it shrieks at us from every screen, 24/7. This is not normal. It‚Äôs not neutral either.

item.title: The Move Faster Manifesto
item.description: I‚Äôve worked in the software industry for over twenty years. I have been a consultant, a line engineer, a director, a founder, and a CTO. I have worked at firms as small as two engineers and as large as fifty thousand. I frequently get asked how to move faster in software. This is what I say. It is easier to describe than it is to do. Rules for moving faster I am not some kind of process relativist; process matters.

item.title: How I Built the Coolest Cyberpunk Gadget for Less Than $10
item.description: Meet MiniZX ESPeon ‚Äî a gadget I‚Äôve been crafting over the past few months. From concept to reality, every aspect of this device is custom-made:‚Ä¶

item.description: I spent the better part of a year dealing with cubital tunnel syndrome, a painful nerve issue. This blog post details how I solved this problem.

item.title: Buried Toggles Begging to be Brought to Light
item.description: Throughout the countless years of research on this blog a common thread always comes up: Some features and toggles are often hidden under mountains of hubris that nobody understands. It could be because the software is under-or-badly documented, that it's 'too-flexible' and made to handle cases that never materialize, or just that...

item.description: April 17, 2025

item.title: Linux is now the best gaming system. ÔΩú fernvenue's Blog
item.description: When it comes to gaming on Linux, many many many people‚Äôs understanding stil remains in the Jurassic era. For the past few years, I‚Äôve been using Linux as my main operating system for both work and gaming. From my personal experience, the gaming experience on Linux is far superior to that of macOS and Windows. I know I know‚Ä¶whenever I mention this, there are always some old-school individuals who come out to say that Linux‚Äôs driver configuration is complex, its game support is not rich enough, and its compatibility issues are significant, among other problems. In this article, I will directly address these issues and let everyone understand how much the gaming experience on Linux has developed by 2025.

item.title: Don't Use Vercel
Decomposing Transactional Systems
item.description: Every transactional system must execute, order, validate, and persist transactions.

item.title: ~fpereiro
item.description: The Pareto Principle, also called the 80/20 rule, states that a few things (the vital few) are much more important than most things (the trivial many). I came across this principle many years ago, in Richard Koch‚Äôs wonderful book.

item.title: Zig and GPUs
item.description: GPU programming used to mean wrangling C++ compilers, bloated SDKs, and vendor-specific toolchains. That‚Äôs changing. You can now write GPU code in modern languages like Rust and Zig with fewer layers. This post walks through the current state of Zig‚Äôs GPU backends and how they stack up across Vulkan, OpenCL, and native ISAs.

item.description: Defold is a free and open game engine used for development of console, desktop, mobile and web games.

item.title: The Fatal Intro Mistake Most Speakers Make (And How to Avoid It)
item.description:
You have just 90 seconds to grab your audience's attention at the start of your talk‚Äîor they've mentally checked out. In this video, I reveal why most speakers waste this critical window and how you can use the "cold open" technique to instantly captivate your audience.
Hi, I'm James, a storytelling technologist who's spoken at over 30 conferences worldwide. I've experienced it all‚Äîfrom people scrolling through their phones to audience members falling asleep in the front row. Let me help you avoid these speaking disasters.
What You'll Learn: - Why starting with your bio is killing your talk before it even begins - How to use the "James Bond technique" to hook your audience immediately - The exact moment when you should introduce yourself (hint: it's not when you think) - Two contrasting real-life examples that demonstrate effective vs. ineffective openings - How to establish credibility without boring your audience
This video builds on our previous lesson about making the audience the hero of your story and shows you exactly how to put this principle into practice in those crucial first moments on stage.
üîó Want more speaking tips? Check out the other videos in this conference speaking series!
üîóFREE TALK PLANNING TEMPLTAE DOWNLOAD - https://speak.jameseastham.co.uk
üëâ Remember: Your audience decides within 90 seconds whether they're going to pay attention to your entire talk. Make those seconds count!
item.author: (James Eastham)

item.title: The Real Reason Windows is Free - And what that costs you!
item.description: üöÄ Ever wondered why Windows 10 was given away for free? Join Dave Plummer, a retired Microsoft engineer from the MS-DOS and Windows 95 era, as he dives into the real reasons behind Microsoft‚Äôs bold move. From declining PC sales and Windows 8‚Äôs backlash to the rise of free macOS and Linux, discover how market pressures and Satya Nadella‚Äôs vision transformed Windows into a service. Uncover the hidden costs‚Äîtelemetry, ads, and a shift to subscriptions‚Äîand what it means for you. Don‚Äôt miss this deep dive into Microsoft‚Äôs strategy! Subscribe for more tech insights from Dave‚Äôs Garage! #Windows10 #Microsoft #TechHistory
item.author: (Dave's Garage)

item.title: (All) Databases Are Just Files. Postgres Too
item.description: If you invest a little time understanding how the components of your database system fit together‚Äînot even the internals, just the externals‚Äîyou‚Äôll be able to move faster, debug better, and build cleaner workflows with more confidence. It only needs some upfront investment of learning the basics and confidence that you can build along the way.

item.title: Google Gemini in .NET: The Ultimate Guide with Jochen Kirstaetter
item.description:
RJJ Software's Software Development Service This episode of The Modern .NET Show is supported, in part, by RJJ Software's Software Development Services, whether your company is looking to elevate its UK operations or reshape its US strategy, we can provide tailored solutions that exceed expectations.
Show Notes "So on my side it was actually, the interesting experience was that I kind of used it one way, because it was mainly about reading the Python code, the JavaScript code, and, let‚Äôs say like, the Go implementations, trying to understand what are the concepts, what are the ways about how it has been implemented by the different teams. And then, you know, switching mentally into the other direction of writing than the code in C#."‚Äî Jochen Kirstaetter
Welcome friends to The Modern .NET Show; the premier .NET podcast, focusing entirely on the knowledge, tools, and frameworks that all .NET developers should have in their toolbox. We are the go-to podcast for .NET developers worldwide, and I am your host: Jamie ‚ÄúGaProgMan‚Äù Taylor.
In this episode, Jochen Kirstaetter joined us to talk about his .NET SDK for interacting with Google‚Äôs Gemini suite of LLMs. Jochen tells us that he started his journey by looking at the existing .NET SDK, which didn‚Äôt seem right to him, and wrote his own using the HttpClient and HttpClientFactory classes and REST.
"I provide a test project with a lot of tests. And when you look at the simplest one, is that you get your instance of the Generative AI type, which you pass in either your API key, if you want to use it against Google AI, or you pass in your project ID and location if you want to use it against Vertex AI. Then you specify which model that you like to use, and you specify the prompt, and the method that you call is then GenerateContent and you get the response back. So effectively with four lines of code you have a full integration of Gemini into your .NET application."‚Äî Jochen Kirstaetter
Along the way, we discuss the fact that Jochen had to look into the Python, JavaScript, and even Go SDKs to get a better understanding of how his .NET SDK should work. We discuss the ‚ÄúPythonistic .NET‚Äù and ‚Äú.NETy Python‚Äù code that developers can accidentally end up writing, if they‚Äôre not careful when moving from .NET to Python and back. And we also talk about Jochen‚Äôs use of tests as documentation for his SDK.
Anyway, without further ado, let's sit back, open up a terminal, type in `dotnet new podcast` and we'll dive into the core of Modern .NET.
Supporting the Show If you find this episode useful in any way, please consider supporting the show by either leaving a review (check our review page for ways to do that), sharing the episode with a friend or colleague, buying the host a coffee, or considering becoming a Patron of the show.
Full Show Notes The full show notes, including links to some of the things we discussed and a full transcription of this episode, can be found at: https://dotnetcore.show/season-7/google-gemini-in-net-the-ultimate-guide-with-jochen-kirstaetter/
Jason's Links: JoKi's MVP Profile JoKi's Google Developer Expert Profile JoKi's website Other Links: Generative AI for .NET Developers with Amit Bahree curl Noda Time with Jon Skeet Google Cloud samples repo on GitHub Google's Gemini SDK for Python Google's Gemini SDK for JavaScript Google's Gemini SDK for Go Vertex AI JoKi's base NuGet package: Mscc.GenerativeAI JoKi's NuGet package: Mscc.GenerativeAI.Google System.Text.Json gcloud CLI .NET Preprocessor directives .NET Target Framework Monikers QUIC protocol IAsyncEnumerable Microsoft.Extensions.AI Supporting the show: Leave a rating or review Buy the show a coffee Become a patron Getting in Touch: Via the contact page Joining the Discord Remember to rate and review the show on Apple Podcasts, Podchaser, or wherever you find your podcasts, this will help the show's audience grow. Or you can just share the show with a friend.
And don't forget to reach out via our Contact page. We're very interested in your opinion of the show, so please get in touch.
You can support the show by making a monthly donation on the show's Patreon page at: https://www.patreon.com/TheDotNetCorePodcast.

item.author: (Jamie Taylor)
